questions.question: Under the check-the-box regulations, a newly formed domestic LLC with two members defaults to classification as:

options.B: A partnership

questions.explanation: Under the check-the-box regulations, a domestic eligible entity with two or more members defaults to partnership classification. A single-member LLC defaults to a disregarded entity. Entities can elect different classification by filing Form 8832, except publicly traded partnerships default to corporate treatment.
questions.tip: Multi-member LLC = partnership. Single-member LLC = disregarded entity. Can elect corporate treatment.

questions.question: To be effective for the current tax year, Form 2553 (S corporation election) must be filed by:

options.A: The end of the tax year
options.B: March 15 of the current year
options.C: The 15th day of the 3rd month of the tax year

questions.explanation: The S election must be filed by the 15th day of the 3rd month of the tax year (March 15 for calendar-year taxpayers) to be effective for the current year. If filed late, it's effective for the following year. Late election relief may be available under Rev. Proc. 2013-30.
questions.tip: S election: March 15 for calendar year. Late elections effective next year unless relief granted.

questions.question: The federal income tax rate for C corporations is:

options.B: A flat 21%
options.D: Based on graduated brackets like individuals

questions.explanation: Since the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017, C corporations are subject to a flat 21% federal income tax rate regardless of income level. The prior graduated rate structure (15% to 35%) was eliminated. Personal service corporations also use the 21% rate.
questions.tip: Flat 21% for all C corps since TCJA. No more graduated rates or PSC 35% rate.

questions.question: A partnership is:

options.A: A separately taxable entity like a corporation
options.B: A pass-through entity where income is taxed to partners
options.C: Never required to file a tax return

questions.explanation: Partnerships are pass-through entities. The partnership files an informational return (Form 1065) but doesn't pay tax. Income, deductions, gains, losses, and credits pass through to partners based on their distributive shares and are reported on each partner's individual return.
questions.tip: Partnerships don't pay taxâ€”partners do. Form 1065 is informational; K-1s allocate items to partners.

questions.question: An S corporation cannot have more than:

options.B: 75 shareholders

questions.explanation: An S corporation is limited to 100 shareholders. Family members (within 6 generations of a common ancestor) can elect to be treated as one shareholder. All shareholders must be individuals, certain trusts, or estates (no corporations or partnerships). Only one class of stock is allowed.
questions.tip: 100 shareholder limit. Family = 1 shareholder if elected. Eligible shareholders: individuals, certain trusts, estates.

questions.question: Which entity structure generally allows the owner to minimize self-employment taxes?

options.B: General partnership
options.D: Single-member LLC taxed as disregarded entity

questions.explanation: S corporation shareholders who work in the business receive wages subject to employment taxes, but their share of S corporation profits (distributions) is not subject to self-employment tax. Sole proprietors, general partners, and disregarded entity owners pay SE tax on all business income.
questions.tip: S corp: salary = employment tax, distributions = no SE tax. Must pay reasonable salary.

questions.question: A corporation owning 25% of another domestic corporation's stock may claim a dividends received deduction of:
questions.explanation: The DRD percentage depends on ownership level: <20% ownership = 50%, 20-79% = 65%, 80%+ = 100%. At 25% ownership, the corporation qualifies for the 65% DRD. The DRD is limited to the applicable percentage of taxable income in most cases.
questions.tip: <20% = 50%. 20-79% = 65%. 80%+ = 100%. Remember taxable income limitation on DRD.

questions.question: Guaranteed payments to a partner are:

options.B: Deductible by the partnership and taxable to the partner as ordinary income
options.C: Treated as distributions reducing partner's basis

questions.explanation: Guaranteed payments are payments to a partner for services or use of capital that are determined without regard to partnership income. They are deductible by the partnership in computing ordinary income and taxable to the recipient partner as ordinary income. They are subject to self-employment tax.
questions.tip: Guaranteed payments: deductible to partnership, ordinary income to partner, subject to SE tax.

questions.question: An S corporation shareholder's basis is increased by which of the following?

options.B: Distributions received

questions.explanation: S corporation shareholder basis is increased by the shareholder's share of ordinary income, separately stated income items, and tax-exempt income. Basis is decreased by distributions, losses, separately stated deductions, and nondeductible expenses. Tax-exempt income increases basis to preserve its tax-free character.
questions.tip: Increases: income (including tax-exempt), capital contributions. Decreases: losses, distributions, nondeductible expenses.

questions.question: The accumulated earnings tax applies to:

options.B: C corporations that accumulate earnings beyond reasonable business needs
options.C: S corporations with excessive retained earnings

questions.explanation: The accumulated earnings tax (AET) is a penalty tax on C corporations that accumulate earnings beyond reasonable business needs to avoid shareholder dividends. The tax rate is 20% of accumulated taxable income. A $250,000 exemption applies ($150,000 for personal service corporations).
questions.tip: AET: 20% penalty on excess accumulation. $250K exemption (PSC = $150K). Must prove business need to avoid.

questions.question: A partner's outside basis in the partnership includes:

options.B: Capital contribution plus share of partnership liabilities
options.D: Fair market value of partnership interest

questions.explanation: A partner's outside basis includes the initial contribution of cash or property basis, plus the partner's share of partnership liabilities, plus allocated income, minus allocated losses, and minus distributions. The liability share increases basis because partners are personally liable for partnership debts.
questions.tip: Partner basis includes share of liabilities. Recourse = sharing ratios. Nonrecourse = profits ratios (generally).

questions.question: The built-in gains (BIG) tax applies to an S corporation that:

options.A: Has always been an S corporation
options.B: Converted from a C corporation and sells appreciated assets within 5 years

questions.explanation: The BIG tax applies when a C corporation converts to S status and has net unrealized built-in gains at conversion. If appreciated assets are sold within 5 years, the net recognized built-in gain is taxed at 21% at the corporate level. The recognition period is 5 years.
questions.tip: BIG tax: C-to-S conversion, asset sales within 5 years, 21% corporate tax on built-in gain at conversion.

questions.question: A corporation can deduct how much of organizational expenses in the first year?

options.A: No deduction allowed; must be capitalized
options.B: Up to $5,000, with excess amortized over 180 months
options.D: Up to $10,000 in the first year

questions.explanation: Organizational expenses up to $5,000 can be deducted in the first year, with the balance amortized over 180 months (15 years). The $5,000 amount is reduced dollar-for-dollar when total expenses exceed $50,000. Start-up expenses have the same treatment.
questions.tip: $5,000 deductible, phased out if total > $50,000. Same rule for start-up costs. Remainder amortized 180 months.

questions.question: Partnership allocations of income and loss must have:

options.B: Substantial economic effect or follow partners' interests in the partnership

questions.explanation: Special allocations (allocations that differ from ownership percentages) are respected for tax purposes only if they have substantial economic effect. This requires that the allocation affect the partners' economic interests (capital account adjustments, liquidating distributions follow capital accounts, deficit restoration).
questions.tip: Special allocations must have economic effect. Capital accounts must reflect allocations; liquidations follow capital accounts.

questions.question: An S corporation with C corporation earnings and profits may lose its S status if passive investment income exceeds:

options.A: 10% of gross receipts for 2 consecutive years
options.B: 25% of gross receipts for 3 consecutive years
options.D: 75% of total income for any year

questions.explanation: If an S corporation has accumulated E&P from C corporation years and passive investment income exceeds 25% of gross receipts for 3 consecutive years, the S election terminates. A tax is also imposed on excess net passive income if passive income exceeds 25% for any single year.
questions.tip: 25% passive income rule only applies if S corp has C corp E&P. Three consecutive years = termination.

questions.question: A corporation is classified as a personal holding company if:

options.B: More than 60% of income is personal holding company income and 5 or fewer individuals own more than 50% of stock
options.D: It has passive losses exceeding active income

questions.explanation: A corporation is a PHC if: (1) at least 60% of adjusted ordinary gross income is PHC income (dividends, interest, rents in some cases, royalties, personal service contracts), AND (2) more than 50% of stock is owned by 5 or fewer individuals at any time during the last half of the year.
questions.tip: PHC: 60% PHC income + 50% owned by 5 or fewer. Penalty tax of 20% on undistributed PHC income.

questions.question: A Section 754 election allows a partnership to:

options.B: Adjust the basis of partnership assets when an interest is transferred or distributed
options.C: Convert capital gains to ordinary income

questions.explanation: Section 754 allows a partnership to elect to adjust the inside basis of partnership property when a partnership interest is transferred (Section 743(b)) or when property is distributed (Section 734(b)). This eliminates discrepancies between a partner's outside basis and share of inside basis.
questions.tip: 754 election: optional basis adjustment on transfers and distributions. Once made, applies to all future transactions.

questions.question: The Accumulated Adjustments Account (AAA) of an S corporation:

options.A: Tracks cumulative taxable income less distributions
options.B: Only applies to S corporations that were never C corporations
options.D: Has a minimum balance of zero (cannot go negative without special elections)

questions.explanation: The AAA tracks cumulative S corporation income less distributions and deductible expenses. It's important for S corps with C corp E&P because distributions come from AAA first (tax-free), then E&P (taxable dividend), then basis. AAA can go negative from losses but not from distributions.
questions.tip: AAA: tracks S corp earnings. Distributions from AAA are tax-free. E&P distributions are dividends.

questions.question: A C corporation's charitable contribution deduction is limited to:

options.B: 10% of taxable income (computed before the contribution deduction)

questions.explanation: Corporate charitable contributions are limited to 10% of taxable income computed before the charitable deduction, DRD, NOL carryback, and capital loss carryback. Excess contributions carry forward 5 years. This differs from individual limits (60%, 50%, 30%, or 20% depending on type).
questions.tip: Corporate charitable limit: 10% of modified taxable income. 5-year carryforward. Individual limits are higher.

questions.question: Hot assets under Section 751 include:

options.B: Unrealized receivables and inventory items

questions.explanation: Hot assets are unrealized receivables (including recapture potential) and inventory items (substantially appreciated if the FMV exceeds 120% of basis). On sale of a partnership interest or certain distributions, gain attributable to hot assets is ordinary income, not capital gain.
questions.tip: Hot assets: receivables + inventory. Convert capital gain to ordinary on sale of interest or distributions.

questions.question: Double taxation refers to:

options.A: Paying both federal and state income tax
options.B: Corporate income being taxed at the corporate level and again when distributed as dividends
options.C: Being taxed in two different states
options.D: Alternative minimum tax and regular tax

questions.explanation: Double taxation is the taxation of corporate income at the corporate level (21% rate) and again at the shareholder level when distributed as dividends (qualified dividend rates). S corporations, partnerships, and LLCs taxed as partnerships avoid double taxation through pass-through treatment.
questions.tip: Double tax: corporate 21% + shareholder dividend tax. Pass-throughs avoid this with single level of tax.

questions.question: A contribution of property to a partnership followed by a distribution of cash to the contributing partner within 2 years is presumed to be:

options.B: A disguised sale subject to gain recognition

questions.explanation: Under the disguised sale rules (Section 707(a)(2)(B)), if a partner contributes property and receives a related distribution within 2 years, the transactions are presumed to be a sale unless the facts establish otherwise. This prevents partners from avoiding gain recognition on property sales to the partnership.
questions.tip: Contribution + distribution within 2 years = presumed disguised sale. Must rebut with facts.

questions.question: In a Section 351 exchange, if a shareholder receives $50,000 cash (boot) and has a $30,000 realized gain, the recognized gain is:
questions.explanation: In a Section 351 exchange, gain is recognized to the extent of boot received, but not in excess of realized gain. Since the realized gain ($30,000) is less than the boot received ($50,000), only $30,000 is recognized. No loss is recognized in a Section 351 exchange.
questions.tip: Recognized gain = lesser of (boot received) or (realized gain). Losses never recognized in 351.

questions.question: An S corporation shareholder's debt basis includes:

options.A: Shareholder's share of S corporation liabilities
options.B: Direct loans from the shareholder to the S corporation
options.C: Bank loans guaranteed by the shareholder

questions.explanation: Unlike partnerships, S corporation shareholders only get debt basis from direct loans they make to the corporation. Third-party loans, even if guaranteed by shareholders, do not increase shareholder debt basis. This is a key difference between S corporations and partnerships.
questions.tip: S corp debt basis: only direct shareholder loans. NO basis for guarantees or corporate debt. Partnership = gets share of all debt.

questions.question: A distribution from a C corporation is treated as a taxable dividend to the extent of:

options.B: Current and accumulated earnings and profits (E&P)
options.C: The fair market value of property distributed

questions.explanation: Corporate distributions are dividends (taxable at qualified dividend rates) to the extent of current and accumulated E&P. Distributions exceeding E&P are a tax-free return of basis, then capital gain after basis is exhausted. Current E&P is allocated pro rata to all distributions during the year.
questions.tip: Dividend = E&P (current, then accumulated). Excess = return of basis. Then capital gain after basis exhausted.

questions.question: Under the 'mixing bowl' rules, if property contributed to a partnership is distributed to another partner within 7 years:

options.A: No gain is recognized by any party
options.B: The contributing partner recognizes precontribution gain
options.C: Only the receiving partner recognizes gain

questions.explanation: Under Section 704(c)(1)(B), if contributed property is distributed to another partner within 7 years, the contributing partner must recognize the precontribution gain or loss that would have been allocated to them. This prevents using partnerships to shift built-in gains to other partners.
questions.tip: 7-year rule: contributed property distributed to another partner = contributing partner recognizes built-in gain/loss.

questions.question: For a Qualified Subchapter S Trust (QSST) to be an eligible S corporation shareholder:

options.B: All income must be distributed currently to one income beneficiary
options.C: It cannot own more than 10% of the S corporation
options.D: The trust must terminate within 21 years

questions.explanation: A QSST must have only one current income beneficiary, and all income must be distributed currently to that beneficiary. The income beneficiary must be a U.S. citizen or resident, and corpus distributions can only go to them during their lifetime. An election must be made for QSST status.
questions.tip: QSST: one beneficiary, all income distributed currently. Alternative: ESBT (can have multiple beneficiaries).

questions.question: In a complete liquidation of a C corporation, the distributing corporation generally:

options.B: Recognizes gain and loss as if assets were sold at fair market value

questions.explanation: In a complete liquidation, the corporation is treated as selling all assets at FMV and recognizes both gains and losses. Shareholders receive liquidating distributions, recognize gain or loss based on FMV received vs. stock basis, and get a FMV basis in the assets. Exception: Section 332 parent-subsidiary liquidations.
questions.tip: Complete liquidation = corporation recognizes all gains/losses. Shareholders get FMV basis. 332 = different rules.

questions.question: Under Section 736, payments for a retiring partner's share of unrealized receivables are treated as:

options.A: Capital gain to the retiring partner
options.B: Section 736(b) payments for partnership property
options.C: Section 736(a) payments (guaranteed payment or distributive share)

questions.explanation: Section 736(a) payments are for goodwill (if not in agreement) or unrealized receivables. They are treated as ordinary income (either guaranteed payments or distributive shares). Section 736(b) payments are for partnership property (including goodwill if in agreement) and result in capital gain.
questions.tip: 736(a) = ordinary income (receivables, goodwill if not in agreement). 736(b) = capital (property, goodwill if stated).

questions.question: A greater-than-2% S corporation shareholder-employee who receives employer-paid health insurance must:

options.A: Exclude the benefit from income like other employees
options.B: Include the benefit in W-2 wages but can claim an above-the-line deduction
options.C: Treat the benefit as a distribution
options.D: Pay a penalty tax on the benefit

questions.explanation: >2% S corporation shareholder-employees cannot exclude employer-paid health insurance. The premiums must be included in W-2 income (subject to income tax, not FICA). However, the shareholder can then claim an above-the-line deduction for self-employed health insurance, resulting in similar treatment.
questions.tip: >2% shareholder: health insurance on W-2, but deduct above-the-line. Net effect similar to exclusion.

questions.question: Section 382 limits the use of NOL carryforwards when:

options.A: A corporation has losses for 3 consecutive years
options.B: There is an ownership change of more than 50 percentage points

questions.explanation: Section 382 limits the use of pre-change NOLs after an ownership change (more than 50 percentage point increase in ownership by 5% shareholders during a 3-year testing period). The annual limitation equals the corporation's value times the long-term tax-exempt rate, designed to prevent trafficking in NOLs.
questions.tip: Section 382: ownership change > 50% triggers annual NOL limit. Prevents buying companies just for their NOLs.

questions.question: A Section 743(b) basis adjustment is mandatory (even without a 754 election) when:

options.B: The partnership has a substantial built-in loss (over $250,000)
options.C: The partnership makes a liquidating distribution

questions.explanation: A downward basis adjustment is mandatory under Section 743 when a partnership has a substantial built-in loss (the adjusted basis of partnership property exceeds FMV by more than $250,000). This prevents transferees from claiming losses attributable to the transferor's built-in loss.
questions.tip: Mandatory 743(b) for substantial built-in loss > $250K. Also mandatory for electing investment partnerships.

questions.question: Above the income threshold, the Section 199A QBI deduction is limited to the greater of:

options.A: 20% of QBI or 10% of W-2 wages
options.B: 50% of W-2 wages or 25% of W-2 wages plus 2.5% of qualified property
options.C: 30% of net income or 50% of gross receipts
options.D: 100% of W-2 wages or 20% of QBI

questions.explanation: Above the income threshold ($232,100 single, $464,200 MFJ for 2024), the QBI deduction is limited to the greater of: (1) 50% of W-2 wages, or (2) 25% of W-2 wages plus 2.5% of the unadjusted basis of qualified property. The deduction cannot exceed 20% of QBI.
questions.tip: W-2 wage limit: greater of 50% wages OR 25% wages + 2.5% of qualified property. Phases in over threshold.

questions.question: A Type A reorganization (statutory merger) is tax-free to shareholders if:

options.A: Only stock is received as consideration
options.B: Continuity of interest is maintained (substantial stock consideration)
options.D: The transaction is completed within 12 months

questions.explanation: Type A reorganizations require continuity of interest (substantial portion of consideration is stock), continuity of business enterprise (target's business continues), and a valid business purpose. Unlike Type B, boot (cash or other property) is permitted but causes gain recognition to the extent received.
questions.tip: Type A: merger or consolidation, boot allowed. Type B: stock-for-stock only, no boot. Type C: substantially all assets for stock.

questions.question: During the post-termination transition period after S status ends, a corporation can:

options.B: Make distributions tax-free to the extent of AAA
options.C: Carry forward S corporation losses indefinitely
options.D: Continue to make S corporation elections

questions.explanation: The post-termination transition period (PTTP) generally extends for one year after S status ends. During this period, cash distributions are treated as coming from AAA (tax-free return of basis) rather than from C corporation E&P. Suspended losses can also offset income during this period.
questions.tip: PTTP: 1 year after termination. Cash distributions from AAA = tax-free. Suspended losses usable.
